\/D:\/repos\/rr\/source\/manual\/input\/: Stride can recognize gestures and trigger corresponding events.
Stride can recognize gestures and trigger corresponding events.
For example, in a strategy game, the player can drag and drop a unit to the battlefield with a <g2>drag</g2> gesture.
For example, in a strategy game, the player can drag and drop a unit to the battlefield with a <g2>drag</g2> gesture.
Gestures can use one or several fingers.
Gestures can use one or several fingers.
All lengths, speeds and error margins of configuration files must use normalized values.
All lengths, speeds and error margins of configuration files must use normalized values.
By default, the input system doesn't recognize gestures, as this requires CPU time.
By default, the input system doesn't recognize gestures, as this requires CPU time.
Create an instance of the configuration class for the gesture you want to recognize.
Create an instance of the configuration class for the gesture you want to recognize.
For example, for the drag gesture, create an instance of @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigDrag'.
For example, for the drag gesture, create an instance of @'Stride.Input.GestureConfigDrag'.
Add the gesture configuration to the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection.
Add the gesture configuration to the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection.
After you activate recognition for a gesture, you can't modify the gesture's parameters.
After you activate recognition for a gesture, you can't modify the gesture's parameters.
If you need to do this, delete the gesture from the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection and create a new entry with new parameters.
If you need to do this, delete the gesture from the @'Stride.Input.InputManager.Gestures' collection and create a new entry with new parameters.
Delete the gesture from the <g1>InputManager.Gestures</g1> collection.
Delete the gesture from the <g1>InputManager.Gestures</g1> collection.
When the input system detects a gesture, it adds a @'Stride.Input.GestureEvent' to the list of <g1>InputManager.GestureEvents</g1>.
When the input system detects a gesture, it adds a @'Stride.Input.GestureEvent' to the list of <g1>InputManager.GestureEvents</g1>.
The event contains information about the gesture and its state, such as its location and the number of fingers used.
The event contains information about the gesture and its state, such as its location and the number of fingers used.
Each gesture has its own associated gesture event class (see below).
Each gesture has its own associated gesture event class (see below).
The <g1>GestureEvent.Type</g1> field indicates which gesture has been recognized.
The <g1>GestureEvent.Type</g1> field indicates which gesture has been recognized.
You can then cast the base gesture event into the gesture-specific event type to have gesture-type-specific information about the event.
You can then cast the base gesture event into the gesture-specific event type to have gesture-type-specific information about the event.
Stride can detect several gestures simultaneously, so the event list can contain more than one item in an update.
Stride can detect several gestures simultaneously, so the event list can contain more than one item in an update.
The list is cleared with every update, so you don't need to clear it manually.
The list is cleared with every update, so you don't need to clear it manually.
In the @'Stride.Input.GestureConfig' classes, you can configure parameters including:
In the @'Stride.Input.GestureConfig' classes, you can configure parameters including:
the number of fingers the gesture uses
the number of fingers the gesture uses
the number and duration of taps the gesture uses
the number and duration of taps the gesture uses
Each gesture has its own configuration class with specific configuration parameters (see below).
Each gesture has its own configuration class with specific configuration parameters (see below).
Stride supports two main types of gesture:
Stride supports two main types of gesture:
<g1>Discrete</g1> gestures (tap, flick, long press) trigger a single event.
<g1>Discrete</g1> gestures (tap, flick, long press) trigger a single event.
<g1>Continuous</g1> gestures (drag and composite) trigger a series of events when the user changes the direction of the gesture.
<g1>Continuous</g1> gestures (drag and composite) trigger a series of events when the user changes the direction of the gesture.
The user touches the screen and quickly removes their finger.
The user touches the screen and quickly removes their finger.
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
To set the number of fingers required for a tap, modify @'Stride.Input.GestureConfig.RequiredNumberOfFingers'.
To set the number of fingers required for a tap, modify @'Stride.Input.GestureConfig.RequiredNumberOfFingers'.
To distinguish single taps from multi-taps, the system uses latency in tap events.
To distinguish single taps from multi-taps, the system uses latency in tap events.
To disable this, set the <g1>GestureConfigTap.MaximumTimeBetweenTaps</g1> field to <g2>0</g2>.
To disable this, set the <g1>GestureConfigTap.MaximumTimeBetweenTaps</g1> field to <g2>0</g2>.
The user touches the screen, performs a quick straight translation, and withdraws their finger(s).
The user touches the screen, performs a quick straight translation, and withdraws their finger(s).
The number of fingers on the screen can't during the gesture.
The number of fingers on the screen can't during the gesture.
To set a minimum length for the flick gesture, use <g1>GestureConfigFlick.MinimumFlickLength</g1>.
To set a minimum length for the flick gesture, use <g1>GestureConfigFlick.MinimumFlickLength</g1>.

The user touches the screen and maintains pressure without removing their finger for a certain period of time (the default time is one second).
The user touches the screen and maintains pressure without removing their finger for a certain period of time (the default time is one second).
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
To change the minimum press length for the long press gesture, modify  <g1>GestureConfigLongPress.RequiredPressTime</g1>.
To change the minimum press length for the long press gesture, modify  <g1>GestureConfigLongPress.RequiredPressTime</g1>.
The user touches the screen, performs a translation, and withdraws their finger(s).
The user touches the screen, performs a translation, and withdraws their finger(s).
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
The number of fingers on the screen can't vary during the gesture.
To restrict the direction of the drag to <g1>vertical</g1> or <g2>horizontal</g2>, use <g3>GestureConfigDrag.DragShape</g3>.
To restrict the direction of the drag to <g1>vertical</g1> or <g2>horizontal</g2>, use <g3>GestureConfigDrag.DragShape</g3>.
The user touches the screen with two fingers and moves them independently.
The user touches the screen with two fingers and moves them independently.
The composite gesture requires exactly two fingers on the screen.
The composite gesture requires exactly two fingers on the screen.
It's triggered when the system detects one of the three basic actions:
It's triggered when the system detects one of the three basic actions:
<g1>Translation</g1>: the user translates two fingers together in the same direction.
<g1>Translation</g1>: the user translates two fingers together in the same direction.
<g1>Scale</g1>: the user moves two fingers closer together or further apart.
<g1>Scale</g1>: the user moves two fingers closer together or further apart.
<g1>Rotation</g1>: the user rotates two fingers around a center point.
<g1>Rotation</g1>: the user rotates two fingers around a center point.
A gesture always has one of four states:
A gesture always has one of four states:
<g1>Discrete</g1> gestures (tap, flick, long press) always have the state <g2>occurred</g2>.
<g1>Discrete</g1> gestures (tap, flick, long press) always have the state <g2>occurred</g2>.
<g3>Continuous</g3> gestures (drag and composite) always begin with the state <g4>began</g4>, followed by any  <g5>changed</g5> states, and end with the <g6>ended</g6> state.
<g3>Continuous</g3> gestures (drag and composite) always begin with the state <g4>began</g4>, followed by any  <g5>changed</g5> states, and end with the <g6>ended</g6> state.
To query the current state of a gesture, use the <g1>GestureEvent.State</g1> field of the triggered gesture event.
To query the current state of a gesture, use the <g1>GestureEvent.State</g1> field of the triggered gesture event.

You can access the list of events triggered by recognized gestures using the <g1>InputManager.GestureEvents</g1> collection.
